awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Uplift and Seismic Structure of the Greater Caucasus
awd_abstract_narration:
This project uses the Greater Caucasus Mountains in southern Asia as a natural laboratory to study the early stages of mountain building.  Using data from over 106 new seismic stations in Azerbaijan, Armenia, Russia, and Georgia, the researchers gain a better understanding of the recent uplift of the Greater Caucasus and the nature of earthquake related deformation in the region. This research helps gain better understanding of the processes that lead to the formation of mountain belts on Earth and the sub surface processes that lead to large earthquakes and volcanoes in a continental collision. This project includes improving seismic hazard assessment in continental deformation belts where thousands of lives and billions of dollars are at risk from recurrent devastating earthquakes including some of the world's largest energy producers. The aim is to improve the scientific community's understanding of earthquake hazards and the forces that are actively deforming the earth in a very young mountain belt.  

The Caucasus region is a logistically and politically challenging region to collect seismic data; however, we have managed to establish collaborative agreement with all of the countries involved in this project to share the data with one another.   Due to a lack of quality data, the region has largely been unexplored in terms of the detailed uppermost mantle and crustal seismic structure thus this work is nearly guaranteed to find first order information concerning deep structure beneath the Greater Caucasus.  This seismic experiment has two components:  (1) a grid of stations spanning the Greater Caucasus and (2) a seismic transect consisting of passive stations spaced at distances of less 5 km that crosses the Greater Caucasus. In addition to the temporary stations, this research integrates data from the national networks to produce high resolution images of the seismic structure. The primary scientific question that this project intends to resolve with the images of the deep subsurface structure is the uplift mechanisms for the Greater Caucasus and how these relate to the uplift mechanisms for mountain belts in general.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The "Collaborative Research: The Uplift and Seismic Structure of the Greater Caucasus" (namely CNET) project was a multi-year project funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF). The goal of CNET was to study the seismic structure and geodynamics of the Caucasus Mountains region. On this project, Michigan State University (MSU) partnered with scientists from the University of Missouri and Oregon State University to deploy a large network of seismic stations across the republics of Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, and adjacent regions of the Russian Federation (Figure 1). Over the course of this 6 year project, seismic stations were deployed in over 150 locations, and collected over 3 Terrabytes of data.  All data will be open and available to researchers around the world. On this project, MSU and the other US institutions worked collaboratively with seismologists and students in each of the partnering countries, which facilitated international collaboration in an area that is difficult to work in.

Overall, the data collected and subsequent analysis has provided us a better picture of the distribution of seismicity and active faults in the region.  This contributes to a better understanding of the tectonic processes in the region.  Of significance, we note that seismicity below and to the north of the eastern Greater Caucasus Range can be unusualy deep. Events in this area that exceed 100 km in depth suggest localized subduction that may be in its initial stage of development, or is the result of an older slab segment that is breaking off and sinking. The better understanding of the seismicty and active fault structures are being incorporated into the seismic hazard evaluation of the region, which is critical for safety in the region.   

MSU focused research on understanding the processes occurring in the upper mantle under the Caucasus region.  Shear wave splitting, one of the only methods that can measure strain at depth by measuring seismic anisotropy, was analyzed for stations deployed in the Caucasus.  Preliminary results (Figure 2) show that there is an overall NE-SW fast anisotropic direction pattern (synonymous of direction of maximum finite strain). What is of interest is that this pattern changes drastically throughout the region, as these anisotropy patterns normally persist for hundreds of kilometers. The results here show different anomalies in the mantle for different areas within the Caucasus. The NE-SW pattern has been imaged throughout the Anatolian Plateau in Eastern Turkey, and continues through the west Lesser and Greater Caucasus. In the central part of the Caucasus, the strength of the anisotropy descreases but the direction stays the same in Georgia. In Armenia, the direction slightly rotates clockwise going soouth and East. there is a "rotational pattern" that occurs in sout-central Armenia that indicates complex anisotropy. In the eastern boundary of the Lesser Caucasus, towards the Kura basin, the anisotropy disappears as al the SKS and SKKS splitting results show no splitting. This could also indicate complex anisotropy, but that is a matter of further studies.

Along the ridge of the Greater Caucasus, the stations show range parallel fast anisotropic direction. This is not surprising for a convergent boundary, as this has been observed in many convergent tectonic regions. However, this anisotropic patterns supports the idea of subduction in the central and eastern Greater Caucasus.

 


Last Modified: 11/05/2024
Modified by: Kevin G Mackey

Images (1 of )
  • This image shows results of our shear wave splitting study from the CNET deployment in the Caucasus. Line orientations indicate the average fast splitting direction for each station. The length of the line is proportional to the delay time between the fast and slow directions.

    Public Domain
    Kevin G Mackey
    Caucasus Shear Wave Splitting

por.por_txt_cntn:
The "Collaborative Research: The Uplift and Seismic Structure of the Greater Caucasus" (namely CNET) project was a multi-year project funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF). The goal of CNET was to study the seismic structure and geodynamics of the Caucasus Mountains region. On this project, Michigan State University (MSU) partnered with scientists from the University of Missouri and Oregon State University to deploy a large network of seismic stations across the republics of Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, and adjacent regions of the Russian Federation (Figure 1). Over the course of this 6 year project, seismic stations were deployed in over 150 locations, and collected over 3 Terrabytes of data. All data will be open and available to researchers around the world. On this project, MSU and the other US institutions worked collaboratively with seismologists and students in each of the partnering countries, which facilitated international collaboration in an area that is difficult to work in.


Overall, the data collected and subsequent analysis has provided us a better picture of the distribution of seismicity and active faults in the region. This contributes to a better understanding of the tectonic processes in the region. Of significance, we note that seismicity below and to the north of the eastern Greater Caucasus Range can be unusualy deep. Events in this area that exceed 100 km in depth suggest localized subduction that may be in its initial stage of development, or is the result of an older slab segment that is breaking off and sinking. The better understanding of the seismicty and active fault structures are being incorporated into the seismic hazard evaluation of the region, which is critical for safety in the region. 


MSU focused research on understanding the processes occurring in the upper mantle under the Caucasus region. Shear wave splitting, one of the only methods that can measure strain at depth by measuring seismic anisotropy, was analyzed for stations deployed in the Caucasus. Preliminary results (Figure 2) show that there is an overall NE-SW fast anisotropic direction pattern (synonymous of direction of maximum finite strain). What is of interest is that this pattern changes drastically throughout the region, as these anisotropy patterns normally persist for hundreds of kilometers. The results here show different anomalies in the mantle for different areas within the Caucasus. The NE-SW pattern has been imaged throughout the Anatolian Plateau in Eastern Turkey, and continues through the west Lesser and Greater Caucasus. In the central part of the Caucasus, the strength of the anisotropy descreases but the direction stays the same in Georgia. In Armenia, the direction slightly rotates clockwise going soouth and East. there is a "rotational pattern" that occurs in sout-central Armenia that indicates complex anisotropy. In the eastern boundary of the Lesser Caucasus, towards the Kura basin, the anisotropy disappears as al the SKS and SKKS splitting results show no splitting. This could also indicate complex anisotropy, but that is a matter of further studies.


Along the ridge of the Greater Caucasus, the stations show range parallel fast anisotropic direction. This is not surprising for a convergent boundary, as this has been observed in many convergent tectonic regions. However, this anisotropic patterns supports the idea of subduction in the central and eastern Greater Caucasus.
